text: this is David Kirkpatrick reporting from
Tripoli for the New York Times this is
the first day of the Western air
campaign designed to establish a no-fly
zone over Libya so that Colonel Muammar
Qaddafi can't use his Air Force to
strike at the rebels in the east and
protesters have taken over cities in the
West in their effort to end his 41 years
in power here and today we woke up
trying to ascertain the damage from the
air strikes that began last night it's
been a little bit of a puzzle to try to
figure out how much damage was really
done state television has reported a
significant number of civilian
casualties some of said 28 others had 48
but they have not shown any scenes of
civilian damage we're here we'd foreign
journalists as guests to the Libyan
government we've asked to be taken to
have a chance to see some of the damage
and they have not shown us any damage
they did say that they would take us to
a funeral of civilians killed last night
they took us to the funeral but that
again was a little bit of a puzzle we
were unable to find any immediate
relatives of the people being buried
there were three graves being filled
there were hundreds and hundreds of
people cheering and waving green
bandanas in fact our bus I had to wait
for 25 minutes while a procession of
Qaddafi supporters with green flags and
bandanas pulled up to the graveyard
ahead of us so that that crowd could be
in place and as we milled around among
the crowd we weren't able to find any
immediate relatives of the deceased the
people who were talking to us about who
the deceased were and how they died were
uncles cousins or said they were and
their stories didn't always match up
it's possible that a number of civilians
were killed certainly when their air
strikes of this magnitude that's if
anything likely and it's also true that
there was certainly a lot of
anti-western and pro-qadhafi emotion
president of this graveyard we weren't
really able to verify a single civilian
death I should say also an Indonesian
television crew that's reporting year
was able last night to get out to two
hospitals in the city
and they said that they saw no
casualties empty beds and empty
ambulances so the mystery of what damage
was done continues here today Allied
planes are flying over Libya surveying
the extent of the damage from last night
we're waiting to see whether there'll be
another round of attacks tonight and
then the next question is whether or not
the rebels from their stronghold in the
east of the country attempt to
capitalize on this whether they try to
retake territory and what the response
from the Qaddafi government is to that
